questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a leading cause of mortality in children aged 1-4 years in developing countries?

options.label: A
options.text: Diarrhoeal diseases

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory infections

options.label: C
options.text: Malnutrition

options.label: D
options.text: Congenital anomalies

questions.correct_answer: D. Congenital anomalies
questions.explanation:
Developing Countries

Developed Countries

Diarrhoeal diseases

Accidents and injuries

Respiratory infections

Congenital anomalies

Malnutrition

Malignant neoplasms

Infectious diseases (e.g., measles, whooping cough)

Influenza

Other febrile diseases

Pneumonia

questions.text: Under which initiative in India are children screened for common health conditions such as birth defects, deficiencies, developmental delays, and diseases up to the age of 18 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat

options.label: B
options.text: Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

options.label: C
options.text: Applied Nutrition Programme

options.label: D
options.text: Mid-day Meal

questions.correct_answer: B. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding a healthful school environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Classrooms should accommodate no more than 40 students with a minimum of 10 sq. ft. per student.

options.label: B
options.text: The interior walls of classrooms should be colorfully painted to create a stimulating environment for students.

options.label: C
options.text: One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students must be provided. Separate facilities for boys and girls.

options.label: D
options.text: Site should be on high-lying land with an area of 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with an additional 1 acre per 100 students.

questions.correct_answer: B. The interior walls of classrooms should be colorfully painted to create a stimulating environment for students.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Location

Centrally situated with proper approach roads, away from busy places like roads, factories, and marketplaces. School premises should be fenced and hazard-free.

Site

High, well-drained land. 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with an additional 1 acre per 100 students. (Option 4)

Structure

Single-story buildings are preferred. Exterior walls should be 10 inches thick and heat-resistant

Classroom

No more than 40 students per room. Minimum 10 sq. ft. per student. (Option 1)

Color of Interior

White interior walls, periodically white-washed.

Lighting

Natural light from the left side, not from the front.

Water Supply

Independent source of safe, potable water, continuous supply distributed from taps.

Lavatory

One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students. Separate facilities for boys and girls. (Option 3)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: KMC involves early and prolonged skin-to-skin contact between the infant and the mother.

options.label: B
options.text: KMC is meant for clinically stable low birth weight (LBW) infants and includes exclusive and frequent breastfeeding.

options.label: C
options.text: KMC should only be provided in hospitals under skilled supervision and proper guidance.

options.label: D
options.text: KMC helps stabilize body temperature, promotes breastfeeding, and prevents infections.

questions.correct_answer: C. KMC should only be provided in hospitals under skilled supervision and proper guidance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding artificial feeding in infants?

options.label: A
options.text: The estimated protein requirement is about 2 g/kg of body weight during the first 6 months; Declines to about 1.5 g/kg by the end of one year.

options.label: B
options.text: Options used in artificial feeding include dried whole milk powder, fresh milk from a cow or other animal, or commercial formulae

options.label: C
options.text: Cow milk is the safest and most commonly used artificial feeding method in developing countries

options.label: D
options.text: The main indications for artificial feeding are failure of breast milk, prolonged illness or death of the mother.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cow milk is the safest and most commonly used artificial feeding method in developing countries
questions.explanation:
Requirement/Guideline

Details

Energy Requirement
  • Infants require an average of 100 kcal per kg of body weight per day (about 150 ml of milk per kg of body weight each day).

Protein Requirement
  • 2 g/kg of body weight during the first 6 months.
  • Declines to about 1.5 g/kg by the end of one year. (Option 1)

Feeding Frequency
  • Infants need feeding at frequent intervals about 6-8 times a day.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect when comparing human milk to cow milk?

options.label: A
options.text: Human milk contains 3 times lower protein, but is rich in amino acids like cysteine and taurine, essential for infants.

options.label: B
options.text: Breast milk is almost completely digested, whereas much of cow's milk protein is excreted undigested.

options.label: C
options.text: The coefficient of uptake of iron is equal in both breast and cow milk, however breast milk contains more Vitamin A and C

options.label: D
options.text: Dilution of cow's milk during the first 2 months is recommended in order to reduce the solute load on neonatal kidneys.

questions.correct_answer: C. The coefficient of uptake of iron is equal in both breast and cow milk, however breast milk contains more Vitamin A and C
questions.explanation:
Nutritional Component

Human Milk

Cow Milk

Protein Content

Lower, easily digestible
(Option 1)

Higher, harder to digest

Essential Amino Acids (e.g., cysteine, taurine)

Rich

Lower

Vitamin A & C

Rich

Lower

Iron

Higher bioavailability

Lower bioavailability

Calcium

Adequate, better absorbed

Higher content, less effectively absorbed

Fat Content

Higher proportion of essential fatty acids (e.g., linoleic, alpha-linolenic)

Lower proportion of essential fatty acids

Digestibility

Almost completely digested

Much is excreted undigested (Option 2)

Risk of Overloading Kidneys

Low

High (hence dilution recommended) (Option 4)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of poor dietary intake for the past several months. On examination, the child has Bitot's spots and other signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the most appropriate treatment plan for this child to correct the Vitamin A deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a single dose of 50,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and repeat the dose the next day.

options.label: B
options.text: Administer a single dose of 100,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and another dose of 100,000 IU after 9 months.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer 50,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and repeat this dose every 6 months until the child turns 5 years.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and the very next day. If clinical signs persist, third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later.

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and the very next day. If clinical signs persist, third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later.
questions.explanation:
Age Range

Vitamin A Dose

Frequency

< 6 months

50,000 IU

1st Dose - Day 0

2nd Dose- Day 1

3rd Dose (if required) - 2-4 weeks later

6-11 months

100,000 IU

1st Dose - Day 0

2nd Dose- Day 1

3rd Dose (if required) - 2-4 weeks later

≥ 12 months

200,000 IU

1st Dose - Day 0

2nd Dose- Day 1

3rd Dose (if required) - 2-4 weeks later

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with bilateral pedal edema, severe wasting, and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm. Which of the following is the feature of initial management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Focus on nutritional and electrolyte balance

options.label: B
options.text: Starter Diet provides 100 kcal per 1000 ml

options.label: C
options.text: Initiation of a home-based nutritious diet

options.label: D
options.text: Provide a catch up diet like F-100

questions.correct_answer: A. Focus on nutritional and electrolyte balance

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding growth charts is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The position of dots is more important than direction

options.label: B
options.text: Flattening of the curve is a sign of growth failure

options.label: C
options.text: 0 to -2 SD signifies normal growth

options.label: D
options.text: 50th percentile is the upper reference for boys in the WHO growth chart

questions.correct_answer: A. The position of dots is more important than direction
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Features of WHO GROWTH CHART : Upper reference (50th percentile for boys) Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls) Between the two references - Normal growth Below lower reference - Malnutrition
  • ↳ Features of WHO GROWTH CHART : Upper reference (50th percentile for boys) Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls) Between the two references - Normal growth Below lower reference - Malnutrition
  • ↳ Features of WHO GROWTH CHART :
  • ↳ WHO GROWTH CHART
  • ↳ Upper reference (50th percentile for boys) Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls) Between the two references - Normal growth Below lower reference - Malnutrition
  • ↳ Upper reference (50th percentile for boys)
  • ↳ Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls)
  • ↳ Between the two references - Normal growth
  • ↳ Below lower reference - Malnutrition

CRITERIA FOR ICDS GROWTH CHART

0 to -2 SD

  • Road to health
  • Green color
  • Advice: Take care of danger signs.

-2 to -3 SD

  • Mild to moderate malnutrition
  • Yellow color
  • Advice: Supplement with diet and breastfeeding.

Below -3 SD

  • Severe malnutrition
  • Red color
  • Refer to a CHC level or above

FEATURES OF ICDS GROWTH CHART

  • Has 3 lines
  • Weight is on the y-axis
  • Age is on the x-axis
  • The first sign of growth failure is the flattening of the curve.
  • The direction of the growth chart is more important than the position of the dots.

 

Features of WHO GROWTH CHART :

  • Upper reference (50th percentile for boys)
  • Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls)
  • Between the two references - Normal growth
  • Below lower reference - Malnutrition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of a severe acute malnourished child?

options.label: A
options.text: MUAC < 11.5 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Low weight for height < -3 SD

options.label: C
options.text: Absence of pitting pedal edema

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of severe body wasting

questions.correct_answer: C. Absence of pitting pedal edema
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Details

Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC)

Less than 11.5 cm (Option 1)

Weight-for-height

Less than -3 SD (standard deviations) on the WHO growth chart. (Option 2)

Bilateral pitting pedal edema

Presence of edema, which is swelling caused by fluid retention, in both feet.

Visible severe wasting

Noticeable and significant loss of body mass, particularly muscle and fat tissue. (Option 4)

questions.text: The image above depicts a measurement used to assess the nutritional status of children. What is being measured?

options.label: A
options.text: Head circumference

options.label: B
options.text: Mid upper arm circumference

options.label: C
options.text: Abdominal girth

options.label: D
options.text: Leg length

questions.correct_answer: B. Mid upper arm circumference
questions.explanation:
COLOUR

Measurement

Status

RED

< 11.5 cm

Severe acute malnutrition

YELLOW

11.5-12.5 cm

Undernourished

GREEN

>12.5 cm

Normal

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 4-year-old child is assessed using Waterlow's Classification. The child's height-for-age is found to be 85%, while weight-for-height is 85%. According to Waterlow's Classification, the nutritional status of this child would be categorized as:

options.label: A
options.text: Normal

options.label: B
options.text: Wasted

options.label: C
options.text: Stunted

options.label: D
options.text: Wasted and Stunted

questions.correct_answer: C. Stunted
questions.explanation:
Weight for Height

Height for Age

Nutritional Status

≥ 80%

≥ 90%

Normal

< 80%

≥ 90%

Wasted

≥ 80%

< 90%

Stunted

< 80%

< 90%

Wasted and Stunted

questions.text: Non-clinical Question: Match the following markers to the type of malnutrition they best assess:- Marker Type of Malnutrition a. Weight-for-height 1. Chronic Malnutrition b. Height-for-age 2. Acute Malnutrition C. Weight-for-age 3. Acute on chronic malnutrition
What is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended by the WHO?
Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to mortality rates in children?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common cause of neonatal mortality is low birth weight.

options.label: B
options.text: Sepsis is a significant cause of both neonatal and infant mortality.

options.label: C
options.text: The Infant Mortality Rate is considered the best indicator of socio-economic development by UNICEF.

options.label: D
options.text: Current IMR is 28/1000 live births.

questions.correct_answer: C. The Infant Mortality Rate is considered the best indicator of socio-economic development by UNICEF.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman gives birth to a baby at 36 weeks of gestation. The baby's birth weight is recorded as 1800 grams. The mother is concerned about the baby's health and asks the pediatrician about the potential risks and necessary care for her newborn. Given the clinical scenario, which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the newborn? 1) The baby is classified as moderately preterm and moderately low birth weight. 2) The baby is classified as extremely preterm and extremely low birth weight. 3) The baby is at a higher risk for infant mortality compared to normal birth weight babies. 4) The baby is expected to double its birth weight by 3 months. 5) The baby is classified as normal term and moderately low birth weight.

options.label: A
options.text: 1 and 3

options.label: C
options.text: 3 and 5

questions.correct_answer: A. 1 and 3
questions.explanation:
Classification

Weight Range

Moderately Low Birth Weight

1500 g to 2499 g

Very Low Birth Weight

1000 g to 1499 g

Extremely Low Birth Weight

Below 1000 g

Classification

Gestational Age

Extremely Preterm

Less than 28 weeks

Very Preterm

28 to 32 weeks

Moderate to Late Preterm

32 to 37 weeks

Term

37 to 42 weeks

Post-term

Beyond 42 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Perinatal Mortality Rate (PMR) is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: PMR includes late fetal deaths from 28 weeks of gestation and early neonatal deaths within the first 7 days of life.

options.label: B
options.text: PMR is considered the best indicator for combined obstetrics and pediatrics care.

options.label: C
options.text: The weight of the fetus should be at least 2 kg to be included in the PMR.

options.label: D
options.text: Birth asphyxia is a significant cause of perinatal mortality.

questions.correct_answer: C. The weight of the fetus should be at least 2 kg to be included in the PMR.

questions.text: What is the current Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in India according to the Sample Registration System (SRS)?

options.label: A
options.text: 30 per 1000 live births

options.label: B
options.text: 28 per 1000 live births

options.label: C
options.text: 25 per 1000 live births

options.label: D
options.text: 20 per 1000 live births

questions.correct_answer: B. 28 per 1000 live births

questions.text: Which of the following defines the Neonatal Mortality Rate?

options.label: A
options.text: Death of a child within 0-28 days of life per 1000 live births

options.label: B
options.text: Death of a child within 0-7 days of life per 1000 live births

options.label: C
options.text: Death of a child within 8-28 days of life per 1000 live births

options.label: D
options.text: Death of a child within 29 days to 1 year of life per 1000 live births

questions.correct_answer: A. Death of a child within 0-28 days of life per 1000 live births
questions.explanation:
Early neonatal mortality rate

(Option 2)

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 0 – 7 days of life / live births) x 1000)

Late neonatal mortality rate

(Option 3)

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 8th – 28 days of

life / live birth) x 1000)

Post-neonatal mortality rate

(Option 4)

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 29th day - 1 year of life / live births) x 1000)

questions.text: A state recorded 150 maternal deaths in a year. The number of live births during the same period was 50,000. The total number of women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is 10,00,000. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for this state?

options.label: A
options.text: 3.0 per 1,000 women of reproductive age

options.label: B
options.text: 1.5 per 1,000 live births

options.label: C
options.text: 300 per 100,000 live births

options.label: D
options.text: 15 per 100,000 women of reproductive age

questions.correct_answer: C. 300 per 100,000 live births

questions.text: What is the minimum number of postnatal visits by ASHA workers recommended in the case of a home delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: 4 visits on Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, and Day 42

options.label: B
options.text: 4 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, and Day 42

options.label: C
options.text: 6 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21, and Day 42

options.label: D
options.text: 7 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21, Day 28, and Day 42

questions.correct_answer: D. 7 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21, Day 28, and Day 42
questions.explanation:
Postnatal Care by ANM

HBNC by ASHA

Home Delivery

Minimum 4 visits on

Day 1,3,7 and 42

Minimum 7 visits on

Day 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

Institutional Delivery

Minimum 3 visits on

Day 3, 7 and 42

Minimum 6 visits on

Day 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

questions.text: Which maternal health initiative launched by the National Health Mission focuses on improving the quality of care in labor rooms and maternity operation theaters?

options.label: A
options.text: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA)

options.label: B
options.text: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

options.label: C
options.text: Dakshata Training

options.label: D
options.text: LaQshya

questions.correct_answer: D. LaQshya
questions.explanation:
Initiative

Aims

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA)

(Option 1)

 

To offer free, comprehensive, and high-quality antenatal care to all pregnant women on the 9th of each month.

Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)

Entitles all pregnant women giving birth in public health institutions to receive completely free services, including cesarean sections, and also covers free transportation.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) (Option 2)

To reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional deliveries among poor pregnant women through financial incentives.

SUMAN - Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan

Free, respectful healthcare with zero service denials, aiming to prevent maternal and newborn deaths. Beneficiaries include all pregnant women, up to 6 months post-delivery, and sick infants.

Dakshata Training

(Option 3)

A training program designed to enhance the skills and competencies of healthcare providers in intrapartum and immediate postpartum care.

questions.text: A 28 y/o pregnant woman, currently at 24 weeks of gestation, visits you for her routine antenatal check-up. She reports feeling excessive thirst and has been urinating more frequently than usual. She also mentions occasional fatigue. Her obstetric history includes a previous pregnancy with a baby weighing 4.2 kg at birth. Which of the following tests would you recommend for her?

options.label: A
options.text: Random Blood Sugar Test (RBS)

options.label: B
options.text: Fasting Blood Sugar Test (FBS)

options.label: C
options.text: Oral glucose challenge test (OGCT)

options.label: D
options.text: HbA1c Test

questions.correct_answer: C. Oral glucose challenge test (OGCT)

questions.text: A 25 y/o primigravida, in her 2nd month of pregnancy, has come to you for her routine antenatal checkup. On further questioning, you find out that she has not been given any vaccinations yet. Which of the following is TRUE regarding vaccination protocols in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: A booster dose of the Td vaccine is enough for this patient

options.label: B
options.text: 3 doses of Td vaccine must be given

options.label: C
options.text: 1st Td dose should be given as soon as possible

options.label: D
options.text: 2nd dose should be given 48 days after the 1st dose

questions.correct_answer: C. 1st Td dose should be given as soon as possible

questions.text: A 23 y/o woman, who works at a construction site, comes to you with obstetric code G1P0L0, in her 2nd trimester for her 2nd routine check-up. She is anemic and has a Hb value of 8.4g/dl. Which of the following would not be the right advice for her?

options.label: A
options.text: She should take 1 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablet daily.

options.label: B
options.text: She should increase her calorie intake

options.label: C
options.text: She should increase her calcium and vitamin A intake .

options.label: D
options.text: She must come for at least 2 more ANC visits

questions.correct_answer: A. She should take 1 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablet daily.
questions.explanation:
Calorie requirements according to NIN (National Institute of Nutrition)
  • Pregnancy: +350 kcal/day.
  • Lactation:
    • 0-6 months: +600 kcal/day.
    • 7-12 months: +520 kcal/day.

Ideal time
  • 1st trimester: No additional calories required.
  • 2nd trimester: 350 kcal/day.
  • 3rd trimester: 450 kcal/day.

Daily allowance for females
  • Sedentary: 1660 kcal.
  • Moderate: 2100 kcal.
  • Heavy worker: 2700 kcal.
    • +350 means we add to sedentary (1660).
